1.1 BACKGROUND

Mirant Delta, LLC (Mirant) owns and operates Pittsburg Power Plant (PPP), an electric power generating facility located in West Pittsburg, California in Contra Costa County. There are seven existing units at PPP: Units 1-4 which have been retired and Units 5-7 which continue to operate for electric power generation.  Units 5 and 6 are each rated at 325 MW and Unit 7 is rated at 720 MW.  The boilers for Units 5 and 6 were manufactured by Babcock and Wilcox and the boiler for Unit 7 was manufactured by Combustion Engineering. 

Mirant has retrofitted the existing Units 5 and 6 at PPP with Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) systems in order to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), as required to comply with Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) Regulation 9, Rule 11, "Nitrogen Oxides and Carbon Monoxide from Electric Power Generating Steam Boilers".  Mirant completed the retrofit of Unit 6 with an SCR system in February of 2002 and completed the retrofit of Unit 5 with an SCR system in June of 2002.  At the time that the Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems were designed and constructed, Mirant had planned to also retrofit Unit 7 with a SCR system.  Since that time, the project to retrofit Unit 7 with a SCR system has been cancelled.  This document addresses the aqueous ammonia systems that are associated with the Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems.

The SCR system utilizes aqueous ammonia to reduce NOx emissions from the generating units. The concentration of ammonia in the aqueous solution is 29.4% by weight. This substance is listed as a hazardous material under both California and federal regulations.

In order to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment, a federal program was established in 1990 as described in Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The California Office of Emergency Services established the California Accidental Relea

se Prevention (CalARP) Program to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur. The CalARP Program specifies the regulated substances, oversees the federal requirements, and determines the requirements for the preparation of a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and offsite accidental release consequence analysis. In Contra Costa County, the Administering Agency overseeing the CalARP program is the Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD).

With the addition of the SCR systems, the quantity of aqueous ammonia that is stored and used at Pittsburg Power Plant is greater than both the Federal and State Threshold Quantities; therefore, a RMP is required. As shown in this RMP, a worst-case release from the PPP aqueous ammonia system would cause the toxic endpoint concentration for ammonia (200yppmv) to occur offsite, in an area of Suisun Bay to which the public has access. Therefore, the process cannot be classified as Program 1. Although, aqueous ammonia is listed as a regulated substance in Section 2770.5 of CalARP regulations, the power generation industry is not specifically required to submit extensive Program 3 RMP requirements, and the CCCHSD has determined that the risk posed by this process does not justify classifying the process as Program 3. Accordingly, this process qualifies for a Program 2 RMP under both the CalARP and federal regulations. In order to fulfill the Program 2 requirements, the following actions were completed:

* Analyze a worst-case and alternative release scenario and provide offsite consequence analysis.

* Describe the site's accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps. Ensure that response actions have been coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies.

* Describe the site's safety program.

* Describe the site's hazard review program.

* Describe the site's operating procedures.

* Describe the site's training programs

.

* Describe the site's maintenance program.

* Describe the site's compliance audit program.

* Describe the site's incident investigation program.

* Provide an external event analysis of the SCR systems, including a seismic analysis.

* Certify the information in this RMP is accurate. 

To ensure continued compliance with the CalARP regulations, Mirant will update this RMP within five years of the most recent update, before any additional regulated substance is brought onsite, before additional aqueous ammonia storage capacity is installed, or if there is a major change that may alter the offsite consequence analysis.

The remainder of this RMP documents these actions. The organization of the RMP follows that provided in the Contra Costa County CalARP Program Guidance Document.



1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Mirant is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. It is the policy of Mirant to conduct business in a manner that protects the environment and the safety and health of the public and its employees by: 

* Meeting all environmental laws, regulations and permit requirements.

* Seeking to ensure that environmental laws, regulations and permit requirements are based on sound science and cost-effective technology. 

* Pursuing opportunities to enhance the quality of the environment. 

* Promoting public and employee understanding of environmental issues and the company's environmental activities. 

* Establishing company and organizational environmental goals and implementation plans. 

* Ensuring that employees are aware of their individual roles and responsibilities in implementation of this environmental policy.

A copy of Mirant's Environmental Policy can be found in Appendix A of the RMP located at the facility.  A copy of Mirant's Safety and Health Policy can be found in Appendix B of the RMP located a

t the facility. In an effort to continue to improve the environmental, safety and health performance and to minimize accidental releases, numerous environmental, safety and health programs are implemented at PPP along with on-going personnel training activities that are described in Section 1.7.1 and 1.7.4 respectively of this RMP. The release prevention programs implemented in conjunction with this RMP strengthens the existing environmental, safety and health programs at PPP. 



1.3 STORAGE AND HANDLING OF REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The only federal and CalARP regulated substance that is stored and handled onsite at PPP is aqueous ammonia, which is used in the SCR systems to reduce NOx emissions from Unit 5 and Unit 6.. In the SCR systems, aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tanks, to a vaporizer, which produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia that is then mixed with the flue gas from the boiler and passed over a reducing catalyst to reduce the NOx emissions from the stack exhaust. 



1.3.1 Ammonia Systems

The systems that handle aqueous ammonia at PPP are the aqueous ammonia storage facility, the aqueous ammonia vaporization skid, and the ammonia injection grid/SCR reactor. 



1.3.1.1 Aqueous Ammonia Storage Facility

The aqueous ammonia storage facility consists of a truck unloading station and three aqueous ammonia storage tanks. The storage facility has been designed and constructed to receive and store aqueous ammonia for three different SCR systems: the retrofitted Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems and a planned SCR system for Unit 7 that has not been installed.  At the present time, the aqueous ammonia storage tanks for the Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems are in service.  The aqueous ammonia storage tank that was installed for the Unit 7 SCR system is currently empty.  The aqueous ammonia storage facility is located near the northern portion of the developed property of the Pittsburg Power Plant, immediately to the west of Unit 7.

The storage facil

ity that currently services the SCR systems for Unit 5 and Unit 6 includes three 21,200-gallon capacity carbon steel storage tanks that are approximately 10 feet in diameter and 38 feet long.  The effective maximum volume of each storage tank is limited to 20,000 gallons through administrative controls which include operating procedures that require a check of the storage tank level prior to filling the tank to confirm that the tank has sufficient free volume to accept the ammonia delivery without exceeding 20,000 gallons.  All tanks have been designed and constructed in compliance with Uniform Building Code Seismic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, 'U' Stamp, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels. The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) and 110F, respectively.

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are supported horizontally on concrete foundations within a walled containment basin approximately 65 feet long by 55 feet wide that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks and running the length of the containment area. This sump is 14 feet wide by 55 feet long and 7 feet deep and provides a volume sufficient to hold 145 percent of the contents of the largest ammonia storage tank, plus the maximum rainfall recorded in the Pittsburg area in 24 hours in the past 43 years (3.03 inches, WRCC 1955-1998). Although the sump has been sized to accommodate rainfall in accordance with the applicable codes, a sump pump has been provided to keep it free of rainwater. The sump pump is interlocked with the ammonia monitoring system so that it does not operate if ammonia vapors are detected.

Aqueous ammonia is delivered to Pittsburg Power Plant via tanker truck. Individual tanker trucks can transport up to 6,500 gallons of aqueous ammonia. The containment area for the unloading area is sized to contain 105 per

cent of the volume of a 6,500-gallon tanker truck. The area is sloped to quickly drain any accidental releases of aqueous ammonia into the central covered containment sump. Each storage tank has an unloading station consisting of an ammonia fill line, where aqueous ammonia is fed from the delivery truck to the tank, and a vapor return line where vapor pressure between the tank and the truck is equalized. 



1.3.1.2 Aqueous Ammonia Vaporization Skid

Aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank to spray nozzles inside the ammonia vaporizer unit that is mounted on the vaporizer skid located near the SCR reactor. The spray droplets are then mixed with a hot air diluent stream in the vaporizer to evaporate the ammonia. The vaporizer produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia in the diluent stream. The diluent stream is then transported to the injection grid.

The aqueous ammonia is pumped through 3/4 inch stainless steel piping from the storage tank to the SCR injection grid.  All electric forwarding pumps and associated piping are located within the walled storage tank containment area. The piping between the storage tank containment area and the nearest edge of the Unit 7 building is contained in a covered trench located under the road and parking area to protect the piping from vehicular traffic. The trench under the road that houses the aqueous ammonia piping drains into the sump under the aqueous ammonia storage tanks in the containment area. In addition, the primary piping is contained within larger diameter PVC piping for all stretches that are not within the storage facility containment area or in the trench under the road, per the request of the Contra Costa Consolidated Fire District (CCCFD). Therefore, secondary containment is provided for all sections of aqueous ammonia piping.



1.3.1.3 Ammonia Injection Grid / SCR

The ammonia injection grid provides additional mixing of the diluent stream and transports it to the SCR.  The SCR reactor convert

s much of the ammonia and oxides of nitrogen from the flue gas into nitrogen gas and water, which are released from the stack.

The ammonia injection grid is located upstream of the SCR reactor. This allows more thorough mixing of the ammonia-laden diluent stream with the turbulent flue gas from the boiler. Although the oxidation-reduction reaction is initiated by the injection of ammonia at the injection grid, all of the reaction is completed in the SCR reactor by passing the mixture over a catalyst composed primarily of titanium and vanadium oxides. The treated flue gas, containing small amounts of residual NOX and excess ammonia, is discharged out the stack.

The SCR process is controlled with feed-forward and feedback control loops. An upstream NOX analyzer measures the NOX concentration at the SCR reactor inlet. A downstream analyzer measures the total NOx concentration downstream of the SCR reactor outlet. The ammonia demand signal, which regulates the rate at which aqueous ammonia is pumped to the vaporizer, is determined from the readings of both NOx analyzers.



1.3.2 Aqueous Ammonia Hazards

The aqueous ammonia solution that is used for the SCR systems at PPP is 29.4 percent ammonia by weight, with the balance of the weight being water. Aqueous ammonia is a corrosive material although the degree of danger associated with the substance is considered minor. Ammonia is not a known carcinogen, but it poses acute and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards to the respiratory system and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards as skin irritations or other effects. Acute health hazards are those that occur from short exposures to airborne ammonia vapor, whereas chronic health effects are those that occur as a result of long-term exposures.

Though there is some insoluble ammonia present in the ammonia solution, the solution has a very low vapor pressure compared to anhydrous ammonia, a more hazardous compound that is also used for SCR systems. The ammonia present

1.7.7 Incident Investigation

The Plant Manager at PPP is ultimately responsible for all aspects of an incident investigation. Incident investigations are conducted whenever a catastrophic release of a hazardous substance occurs that requires an agency notification or results in injuries or illnesses that require medical attention.  Incident investigations are also conducted for near misses that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous material or a potential injury or illness.  The primary purpose of the incident investigation is to identify the underlying root causes of the incident, and to develop and implement corrective actions to prevent the incident or similar incidents from reoccurring.  Incident reports are distributed to all Mirant facilities in order to reduce repeat occurrences and to share the lessons learned.  The incident investigation program at PPP is beneficial to release prevention by ensuring that any incident or potential incident will not be repeated, thus reducing the chance of future incidents.

All incidents requiring an investigation, including near miss incidents are reported immediately to the appropriate department supe

If the ammonia evaporates from the solution, the ammonia vapor is irritating at levels above a few parts per million by volume (ppmv) and acutely toxic in high concentrations. A one-hour average ammonia vapor concentration above 200 ppmv could cause respiratory irritation to exposed individuals. 

Ammonia vapor is flammable in air at concentrations of 16 percent to 25 percent, but requires a very high temperature source for ignition. Ammonia concentrations directly above an aqueous ammonia spill never approach these concentrations; therefore, aqueous ammonia has no explosive flammability potential.



1.4 WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

An offsite consequence analysis was performed to examine the significance of an accidental release of aqueous ammonia in a worst-case scenario and 2 slightly more realistic alternative scenarios.  



1.5 MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

Mirant is dedicated to reducing any risks associated with the storage and handling of the aqueous ammonia for the SCR systems at PPP. To meet Mirant's strict goal of accident free operation, a management system has been developed to oversee the implementation of the various RMP elements.  In this management system, the Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements. An organizational chart that shows the names and positions of those persons which have been assigned responsibility for implementing the individual RMP elements and defines the lines of authority is provided in Appendix C of the RMP located at the facility.  Each position which has been assigned responsibility for the different RMP elements reports changes that affect the RMP to the Plant Manager who ensures that all affected elements of the RMP are updated appropriately and that the local CUPA is kept abreast of all changes to the RMP.  The individual RMP elements, such as training, emergency respon

se, etc., are outlined in this RMP.  

To ensure continued compliance with the CalARP regulations, Mirant will update this RMP within five years of the most recent update, before any additional regulated substance is brought onsite, before additional aqueous ammonia storage is installed, or if there is a major change that may alter the offsite consequence analysis.  At PPP, records supporting the different aspects of the RMP are maintained for at least five years. 

The concentration of aqueous ammonia is not high enough to be regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. 



1.6 CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS  

Safety was the foremost consideration when designing the aqueous ammonia storage facility.  The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are enclosed within a walled containment basin that is sloped to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks that runs the length of the containment area. There is also a walled containment pad under the tanker truck unloading facility that drains rapidly into the covered sump under the tanks in the event of a spill.

Many accident prevention safeguards have been implemented within the aqueous ammonia storage area. For example, in the event of a power outage, standby backup power needed for all required electrical systems, such as monitors and alarms, is provided by an Uninterruptable Power Supply. Also hot work permits are required for specific activities that present the potential for fire, and personnel involved in such operations receive appropriate training. 

Other safety features of the aqueous ammonia storage facility include: 

* Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms,

* Eyewash and shower station,

* Piping and connections for washdown of containment basin with clean water,

* Permanent lighting,

* Lightning protection,

* Truck barrier posts to protect ammonia tanks and delivery lines,

* Liquid level indication and high-level alarm for each tank, easily visible from th

e unloading position,

* Indication of tank level, system pressures, pressure relief valve position and alarm status in the plant control room,

* Shut-off valves located on the tank fill lines, which will close automatically if the emergency high-level alarm is triggered,

* Local manual controls for all pumps,

* Vacuum breaker on each storage tank,

* Safety equipment (for two personnel) including: two sets of escape respirators, ammonia cartridges for the respirators, two pairs of ammonia-resistant gloves, two pairs of ammonia-resistant boots, two ammonia-resistant aprons, two pairs of goggles, one first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher. 

These safeguards have been built as part of the aqueous ammonia storage facility.  In addition, area sensors have been installed in the aqueous ammonia storage facility area and near the ammonia vaporizer skid to monitor ambient ammonia concentrations. Alarms are designed to annunciate in the control room with local audible alarms for ammonia releases at the facilities.

To minimize impacts from accidental releases, workers have been trained in the safe handling of hazardous materials, use of response equipment, procedures for mitigation of a release, and coordination with local emergency response organizations. To avoid or minimize impacts from an accidental release of hazardous materials, nonhazardous or less hazardous materials is used, where possible, and engineering controls have been implemented. For example, aqueous ammonia was selected for the SCR system over anhydrous ammonia, because it is less hazardous.



1.7 PROGRAM 2 PREVENTION PROGRAMS



1.7.1 Safety Information

The only toxic chemical addressed in this Risk Management Plan is aqueous ammonia at a concentration of 29.4% by weight in water. This chemical is stored in two 20,000-gallon carbon steel storage tanks and used in the liquid state as a reagent for a required air pollution control system. The aqueous ammonia is heated and vaporized prior to injection

into the boiler exhaust stream, where it reacts with a catalyst to reduce NOx emissions. The potential health risks associated with aqueous ammonia are discussed in Section 1.3.2.

Mirant has developed an extensive safety program to reduce the risks associated with the handling of hazardous materials such as aqueous ammonia. The purpose of the safety program is to protect Mirant employees, neighbors, and the Pittsburg community from health risks associated with the operation of PPP. The program applies to the PPP site only. Safety program objectives include the implementation of bulleted items below. The potential for serious accidental releases is greatly reduced by maintaining a strong safety program. Key aspects of this program are described in the remainder of this section. Personnel that work with the aqueous ammonia system utilize the safety program by attending annual safety training classes and always have access to safety information such as procedures for the Lockout/Tagout and Confined Space programs, and other safety practices via the computer network.  Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for aqueous ammonia (see Appendix D of the RMP located at the facility) and other hazardous materials can be accessed in electronic or hard copy form through the 3E Corporation and are also maintained in hardcopy form in the Environmental, Safety and Health library on the 2nd floor of the Administration Building at PPP. Safety training records and changes to process safety information are documented and kept on site for 5 years.

Mirant Delta has ensured that the SCR systems at PPP have been designed and constructed in compliance with applicable and recognized codes and standards.  This was achieved with thorough design reviews of design drawings and equipment specifications, shop inspections and testing of critical equipment and components, and field testing and inspections performed by outside parties.

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks comply with Uniform Building Cod

e Seismic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, 'U' Stamp, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels. The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) and 110F, respectively and a minimum design temperature of -20F. 

The piping from the aqueous ammonia storage tank to the SCR reactor is constructed to the ANSI/ASME B31.1 standard.  The expected maximum flow rate of aqueous ammonia from the storage tanks to the vaporizers under 100% load is 35 gallons per hour each for Unit 5 and Unit 6. The vaporizer is designed to operate within a temperature range of 0 to 750 F, a pressure range of - 14.7 to 10 psig, with an air flow rate up to 6000 lb/hr and a maximum aqueous ammonia flow rate of 250 lb/hr. The vaporizer is built of 316 stainless steel packing, to the ANSI/ASME B31.1 standard.

A copy of Mirant's Safety and Health Policy is provided in Appendix B of the RMP located at the facility.  Safety information about aqueous ammonia, the SCR system and its ancillary equipment is described in the SCR Safety Information Binder, which is maintained at PPP. In a continuing effort to improve and ensure proper implementation of the environmental, safety and health programs and policies, the following measures are regularly employed:

* Mirant's Compliance Audit Program - Mirant's corporate office from Atlanta, Georgia performs periodic environmental, safety and health audits.  The purpose of these audits is to assess the overall adequacy of the environmental, safety and health programs and management system and to provide a reasonable assurance of compliance with all applicable regulations and Company requirements.  Corporate audits involve visual walk downs of the facility, as well as interviews with management, operations and maintenance personnel.  An audit report is prepared with recommendations, resolutions and due dates.

y tailboard meeting, in which safety and health issues and concerns are raised, safety & health training is conducted, or other environmental, safety and health information is communicated.

Changes to the safety program may be made at the discretion of the Safety Engineer on an as-needed basis, but are typically made as a result of system modifications, incident investigations, issues raised in daily safety tailboard meetings, or directives from the Safety Committee.



1.7.2 Hazard Review

The original Hazard Review for this process was completed at the PPP facility on January 22, 2002. The focus of this hazard review was the SCR retrofit and corresponding ammonia systems for Units 5, 6, and 7. 

The participants that conducted the hazard review of the SCR systems were: 

* Tom Bertolini, Senior Environmental Engineer, Mirant,

* Bob Jones, Environmental Coordinator, Mirant,

* Jeff Bricker, Senior Environmental Engineer, Mirant,

* Joe Sutton, Senior Project Engineer, Mirant,

* Tim Hamilton, Safety Manager, Mirant,

* Lynn Christensen, Power Plant Technician, Mirant, 

* Allen Armstrong, the Western Regional Manager of Ammonia Products and Services for LaRoche Industries (the ammonia vendor),

* Thomas Wright, a Senior Account Manger of Ammonia Products and Services for LaRoche Industries (the ammonia vendor),

* Don Nixon, Accidental Release Prevention Specialist from the Contra Costa Health Services Department, (present to observe only),

* Dave Einolf, Environmental Consultant with expertise in PHAs/Hazard Reviews from URS and facilitator of the Hazard Review,

* Leslie Fischbein, Staff Scientist from URS, the consultant that lead the RMP development, and 

* Richard Ryan of the CCCFD was also invited to the review, but did not attend. 

These participants were selected such that potential problems with the ammonia systems would be viewed from seve

ral different perspectives. It was intended that at least one participant have experience with the design of the SCR and ammonia systems, the operation and maintenance of these systems, procedures for unloading of ammonia, and safety issues and procedures related to these systems. Participants discussed potential pitfalls of the SCR and ammonia systems by answering questions from a detailed What-If checklist. The What-If checklist suggested events and conditions that could possibly lead to a release of aqueous ammonia from the new systems. The What-If checklist method of hazard review was selected for its versatility and simplicity. In addition, Dave Einolf of URS (who has facilitated many PHAs/Hazard Reviews using a What-If checklist) was available to facilitate the Hazard Review at the PPP and had developed a checklist specifically for ammonia storage, handling, and SCR processing. The What-If checklist was one of the hazard review methods suggested by the CCCHSD, and the CCCHSD approved the specific checklist prior to the hazard review. 

The vast majority of these potential pitfalls described in the checklist were nullified by carefully planned design features of the new systems. Aspects of the design discussed in the hazard review that minimize the potential for many hazards include: secondary containment for all tanks and piping that hold aqueous ammonia; selection of materials to avoid problems with corrosion or vibration; selection of equipment with few moving parts; the deployment of ammonia detectors at key locations; and redundancy in control and safety measures. Several recommendations were made to further reduce the potential hazards. These recommendations, listed below, are primarily procedural and were implemented or resolved before aqueous ammonia arrived on-site.

* Ensure that the standard operating procedures include LaRoche specifications for chocking of delivery truck wheels.

* Develop standard operating procedures for balancing of tanks. 

* E

nsure design basis is included in safety information.

* Relief valves should have rain caps, and caps are to be included in inspections.

* Ensure that initial start-up procedure includes review of caps and flanges.

* Consider a collision barrier where piping exits the underground trench and moves up the wall of Unit 7. 

* Ensure that the removal from service procedure includes provision for inspecting seal caps. 

* Ensure critical valves are labeled prior to startup. 

* Evaluate assembly area locations and Emergency Response plan, if current assembly locations are downwind of the ammonia storage facility. 

* Establish set routes within the PPP for aqueous ammonia trucks to access tanks. 

* Consider signage prohibiting combustibles near the ammonia storage area.

1.7.3 Operating Procedures

The PPP Operations Supervisor is responsible for the development, implementation, and updating of the operating procedures at PPP. The purpose of these operating procedures is to ensure that plant operations are performed in an appropriate, safe, and consistent manner. These operating procedures apply to operations at PPP only. The main objective of the operating procedures is to provide a description of correct methods for performing work-related tasks to Mirant personnel. Well-developed and implemented operating procedures ensure that tasks are performed correctly, safely, and with the appropriate frequency. Clearly, adherence to good operating procedures reduces the risk of incidents including accidental releases. All operating procedures are maintained on the company network, so that all employees can easily access the procedures from any computer at the plant. Printed versions of the procedures are also kept in the control room. The operating procedures are updated whenever a major change to the SCR systems occurs and before the startup of the changed system.  Personnel that work with the SCR system receive initial training on the applicable operating procedures, or when the procedures change. All operating procedures involving the aqueous ammonia systems at PPP were developed by Mirant except the SCR operating procedure that was developed by

Babcock and Wilcox, the designers of the SCR system. Additionally, the ammonia unloading procedure is a modified version of the ammonia unloading procedure developed by La Roche Industries, the ammonia vendor.

The operating procedures contain a description of the procedures required to startup the entire SCR system, whether this is the initial startup, a startup following a normal or emergency shutdown, or a major change that requires a hazard review. These procedures also describe the operating limits of the SCR. Procedures are also in place for system shutdown under both normal and emergency conditions. Normal operations of the entire SCR system are also described. Temporary and emergency operations are conducted in the same manner as normal operations. Other procedures have been developed for the unloading of the aqueous ammonia from a tanker truck to the storage tanks, feed pump operation, sump pump operation, and ammonia detection systems operation. All of the above procedures are contained in the SCR Training Program Manual, which is maintained at PPP. 

Safety and health considerations for the safe handling of aqueous ammonia are discussed in Section 1.7.1 and in the MSDS sheets. The following systems have been implemented in the aqueous ammonia storage facility to ensure safe operations of the aqueous ammonia systems.

1. Shutoff valves on the aqueous ammonia feed line, which will close automatically if:

* The low flue gas flow rate alarm is triggered, or

1.7.4 Training

The Operations Supervisor is responsible for implementing, updating and recording all of the operator training programs at PPP. An effective training program is essential to safe, efficient operations with hazardous materials such as aqueous ammonia. Employees must be provided with effective information and training on hazardous chemicals in their work area at the time of their initial assignment, and whenever a new physical or health hazard the employees have not previously been trained about is introduced into their work area.

Information and training may be designed to cover categories of hazards (e.g. flammability, carcinogenicity) or specific chemicals. Chemical-specific information must always be available through labels and MSDSs. Employees are informed of any operations in their work area where hazardous chemicals are present, and of the location and availability of the written hazard communication program, including the required list of hazardous chemicals, and the required MSDSs.

The SCR Training Program Manual, which resides at PPP, informs employees about the equipment used with the SCR system, the controls and operations involved with the SCR system, how

to conduct routine maintenance, how to troubleshoot problems in the system, and how to safely operate and handle the system.

Initial training at PPP includes at least the following:

* Methods and observations that may be used to detect the presence or release of a hazardous chemical in the work area

* The physical and health hazards of the chemicals in the work area

* The measures employees can take to protect themselves from the hazards, such as appropriate work practices, emergency procedures, and personal protective equipment (PPE) used

* The hazard communication program, including an explanation of the labeling system and MSDSs, and how employees can obtain and use the appropriate hazard information.

Initial and refresher training are documented through personnel training session sign-in sheets.

All Power Plant Technicians (Operations, Electrical & Mechanical Maintenance, Support Services, Technical Services) and Environmental, Safety and Health personnel receive annual refresher training, or more frequent training if necessary, about emergency response plans and relevant safety and health issues. Additional hazardous materials training is conducted for personnel working directly with the aqueous ammonia systems. 

Training is conducted whenever:

* The job presents identified hazards

* Changes in job assignment impact hazard exposures

* New or previously unidentified hazards are identified as part of the job

* Work procedures or practices are developed or changed which may produce new hazards

* New substances, equipment, or tools are introduced that may present a hazard.

To verify competency, written tests are administered at the end of each training session. On-going personnel training programs at PPP include, but are not limited to the following:

* Ammonia Awareness

* Asbestos Awareness

* First Responder Awareness

* Hazard Communication

* Safety and Health Program

* Personal Protective Equipment Awareness

* Hearing Conservation

* Respirat

ory Protection Awareness

* Hazardous Waste Management

* Bloodborne Pathogens

* Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan

* Confined Space Program

* Ergonomics

* First Aid/Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR)/Automated External Defibrillator (AED)

* Lockout/Tagout

* Lead Awareness

* Incipient Fire Response

To ensure that contractors that work for Mirant are adequately trained, the following policies are implemented at PPP:

* As part of the contractual arrangement between any outside contractor and Mirant, the contractor is responsible for complying with OSHA Hazard Communication regulations and the Mirant Hazard Communication Plan. Contractors are required to make available, upon request, a copy of their current Hazard Communication Plan.

* Contractors working on Mirant company property must be notified by Mirant of hazardous chemicals to which contractor's employees may be exposed, and appropriate control measures needed to limit such exposure. Contractors must be notified of the location and contents of the Mirant site hazard communication plan. Proper controls must be established to ensure that Mirant operations do not expose the contractor's employees to known safety and health hazards. Contractors must be notified of precautionary measures to protect themselves while on the job and in the event of an emergency (e.g. alarms, evacuation routes, etc.)

* Copies of MSDSs for all chemicals the contractor's employees may be exposed to are provided to the contractor upon request. Likewise, all contractors are required to furnish Mirant with MSDSs for all hazardous chemicals that are planned to be brought on site upon request, prior to bringing the chemicals on site.



1.7.5 Maintenance

Both the Mechanical Maintenance Supervisor and the Technical Maintenance Supervisor are responsible for the aqueous ammonia system maintenance program, which includes implementing, recording, and updating the program. Maintenance procedures are ava

ilable from the Mechanical Maintenance Supervisor and the Technical Maintenance Supervisor at PPP. The majority of the procedures were obtained or developed from equipment manuals and vendors. The purpose of the maintenance program is to ensure that plant structures and equipment are kept in optimal working condition. This maintenance program applies to structures and equipment at PPP only. The objectives of the maintenance program are to facilitate scheduled inspections of plant structures and equipment, enable plant personnel to recognize abnormalities in the appearance or functionality of these structures and equipment, and to prompt repairs or other actions as a result of the inspections. A well developed and implemented maintenance plan ensures that structures and equipment are kept in good operating condition and do not pose health risks due to lack of maintenance. Clearly, adherence to good maintenance program reduces the risk of incidents including accidental releases. All personnel involved with the maintenance of the SCR systems have been trained and records of the training are maintained. 

Maintenance of major SCR equipment is performed on vendor-recommended basis and inspections are conducted in a timely manner. The periodic equipment inspections are documented in the company computer-based maintenance tracking system.  

Existing administrative requirements for the maintenance program at PPP include periodic inspections, inspection review, inspection follow-up (planning and repair), and recordkeeping. Trained personnel perform periodic inspections.  Inspection findings are reviewed by the Maintenance Supervisors. The Maintenance  Supervisors determine if any follow up action (such as equipment repair or replacement) is required. Maintenance of SCR components are accomplished in accordance with the guidelines of the SCR Training Program Manual. Other maintenance procedures are developed by the Maintenance Supervisors. Recordkeeping of maintenance and in

spections are prompted and organized by MAXIMO.



1.7.6 Compliance Audits

Compliance audits motivate employees to thoroughly follow safe operating and maintenance procedures as well as uncovering shortcomings of these procedures and providing a formal structure in which to address these shortcomings. Improving the employee motivation and the quality of the procedures used by employees will reduce the probability of an accident. To ensure that the procedures and practices outlined above are adequate and being followed, a compliance audit shall be conducted at least every three years. The compliance audit shall be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. Mirant assigns the responsibility for this audit to the Environmental Department. A report shall be created that addresses any deficiencies, along with suggested solutions. The two most recent compliance audit reports shall be retained onsite, though this does not apply to any compliance audit report that is more than five years old.

The developed compliance audit program satisfies the regulatory requirements of Section 2755.6 of the CalARP regulation. The compliance audit team training includes the imparting of a thorough understanding of the CalARP regulations and a review of the Guidance for Auditing Risk Management Plans/Programs. Although this guidance is intended for regulators, the checklist in Annex C of the Guidance document is followed. The compliance audits shall be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

1.8 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the past 5 years at the facility there have been no accidents involving regulated substances or other extremely hazardous subs

tances that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

On April 21, 1997, over 10 years ago, while the PPP was under the ownership of PG&E, there was a small release of a extremely hazardous substance. An external boiler waterwall tube ruptured on the north side of the Unit 5 boiler. The pressure of the steam exiting the tube penetrated the boiler insulation and siding, releasing steam containing asbestos particles from the insulation material. A small amount of asbestos containing material was deposited in the area northeast of the plant. This area included a small park just across the northeast plant boundary, and the western portion of the Pittsburg Marina. Most of the material remained onsite. All impacted areas onsite and offsite were appropriately cleaned. The Community Warning System was activated, though no evacuation or sheltering-in-place was required. There were no injuries or fatalities due to this incident. As a result of this incident, a failure analysis was performed to determine the root cause of the boiler tube failure. Also, an aggressive boiler tube inspection program was implemented and as a result of the inspections, waterwall tube sections of the boiler were replaced. The boiler tube inspections are ongoing.

Since the change of ownership at PPP, accidents have been avoided by adhering to the safety and environmental programs listed in Section 1.7.1, continually improving the personnel safety training program and adhering to a strict maintenance program for all equipment involved with the storage and handling of hazardous substances. 



1.9 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

PPP has coordinated emergency response programs with the CCCHSD and the CCCFD. Periodically, the fire department inspects the facilities that store and handle flammable hazardous materials at PPP to ensure that the applicable Uniform Fire Co

de requirements are being met. The CCCFD visits PPP approximately once per year to practice a simulated emergency at the plant in order to ensure timely, effective, safe response plans.

In the unlikely event of an accidental release of a hazardous substance, PPP utilizes an alphanumeric paging system as its primary emergency notification system for all onsite personnel. The system provides written information regarding the emergency. If the release could result in an offsite public health concern, the emergency coordinator or incident commander shall notify Contra Costa County officials to determine if the community warning system (CWS) should be activated. All community notifications, whether initiated manually or automatically, are coordinated with the CCCFD. 

The above notification procedures are explained in detail in the Facility Emergency Plan along with procedures for minimizing the impact of an incident, appropriate response activities for each hazardous substance onsite, and the phone numbers to contact both on and offsite emergency response personnel. The section of the Facility Emergency Plan addressing the aqueous ammonia has been included in Appendix G of the RMP located at the facility. The Facility Emergency Plan is updated and employees are retrained as new substances or emergency procedures are implemented at the PPP facility and an update log is maintained within the Plan. 

PPP personnel that can respond to an incidental release have successfully completed training in respiratory protection, hazard communication, Emergency Action Plan, use of personal protective equipment and decontamination procedures.
